CatDescriptText: McKinley Wade, Whiteside Road and Eli Herring, florist helper, North Side, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, January 28, 1961, pg. 21 with question: "Do you favor legislation or voluntary (appealing to the souls and conscience of men) methods, like arbitration, mediation, persuasion, etc., to obtain civil rights for minorities?" McKinley Wade's answer reads: "I favor laws becuase it gives each individual an equal chance."  Eli Herring's answer reads: "Laws, because you don't get anything by persuasion..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of McKinley Wade wearing dark fedora, eyeglasses, and light colored coat, standing on sidewalk in front of flecked building; Portrait of Eli Herring wearing fedora and light colored coat, standing on sidewalk with other people and storefronts
